channel.title: News : NPR
channel.description: NPR news, audio, and podcasts. Coverage of breaking stories, national and world news, politics, business, science, technology, and extended coverage of major national and world events.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2023 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: Ex-Starbucks manager awarded $25.6 million in case tied to arrests of 2 Black men
item.description: Jurors in federal court awarded $25.6 million to a former Starbucks regional manager who alleged that she and other white employees were unfairly punished after the arrests of two Black men in 2018.
item.content:encoded:
Jurors in federal court awarded $25.6 million to a former Starbucks regional manager who alleged that she and other white employees were unfairly punished after the arrests of two Black men in 2018.

(Image credit: Gene J. Puskar/AP)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: The Mississippi police officer who shot an 11-year-old is now suspended without pay
item.description: The move from the Board of Aldermen comes nearly a month after 11-year-old Aderrien Murry was left seriously injured after Capers shot him in the chest responding to a 911 call Murry had made.
item.content:encoded:
The move from the Board of Aldermen comes nearly a month after 11-year-old Aderrien Murry was left seriously injured after Capers shot him in the chest responding to a 911 call Murry had made.

(Image credit: AP)
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Franklin

item.title: Robert Gottlieb, celebrated editor of Toni Morrison and Robert Caro, has died at 92
item.description: Gottlieb, whose work helped shape the modern publishing canon, edited fiction by future Nobel laureates, spy novels by John le Carré, essays by Nora Ephron and Caro's nonfiction epics.
item.content:encoded:
Gottlieb, whose work helped shape the modern publishing canon, edited fiction by future Nobel laureates, spy novels by John le Carré, essays by Nora Ephron and Caro's nonfiction epics.

(Image credit: Michael Lionstar/Knopf via AP)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: Read the highlights of Trump's arraignment transcript
item.description: The U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Florida has released the transcript for former President Donald Trump's arraignment hearing Tuesday afternoon. Read it here.
item.content:encoded:
The U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Florida has released the transcript for former President Donald Trump's arraignment hearing Tuesday afternoon. Read it here.

(Image credit: Elizabeth Williams via AP)
item.dc:creator: Carrie Johnson

item.title: Ken Jennings knows about everything. That now includes the afterlife
item.description: You might know Ken Jennings as the Jeopardy! genius-turned host. But he's also an author, and a guy who really wants to know stuff.
item.content:encoded:
You might know Ken Jennings as the Jeopardy! genius-turned host. But he's also an author, and a guy who really wants to know stuff.

(Image credit: Getty Images)
item.dc:creator: Manuela López Restrepo

item.title: Nearly a year later, most Americans oppose Supreme Court's decision overturning Roe
item.description: The latest Gallup poll also finds increased political polarization. Some 60% of Democrats said abortion should be legal under any circumstances, compared with 8% of Republicans.
item.content:encoded:
The latest Gallup poll also finds increased political polarization. Some 60% of Democrats said abortion should be legal under any circumstances, compared with 8% of Republicans.

(Image credit: Jacquelyn Martin/AP)
item.dc:creator: Sarah McCammon

item.title: A court in Guatemala has sentenced a prominent journalist to 6 years in jail
item.description: Human rights groups have called the trial of journalist José Rubén Zamora a politically motivated sham after his newspaper uncovered corruption in the Central American country.
item.content:encoded:
Human rights groups have called the trial of journalist José Rubén Zamora a politically motivated sham after his newspaper uncovered corruption in the Central American country.

(Image credit: Johan Ordoñez/AFP via Getty Images)
item.dc:creator: Eyder Peralta

item.title: UPS workers facing extreme heat win a deal to get air conditioning in new trucks
item.description: The agreement with the Teamsters comes after complaints from labor leaders, workers and their families that the company has not done enough to protect drivers from scorching temperatures on the job.
item.content:encoded:
The agreement with the Teamsters comes after complaints from labor leaders, workers and their families that the company has not done enough to protect drivers from scorching temperatures on the job.

(Image credit: Nam Y. Huh/AP)
item.dc:creator: Joe Hernandez

item.title: White House press secretary Karine Jean-Pierre violated the Hatch Act, watchdog says
item.description: The White House press secretary receives a warning, as a federal agency finds that the White House Counsel's Office "did not at the time believe that Ms. Jean‐Pierre's remarks were prohibited."
item.content:encoded:
The White House press secretary receives a warning, as a federal agency finds that the White House Counsel's Office "did not at the time believe that Ms. Jean‐Pierre's remarks were prohibited."

(Image credit: Andrew Caballero-Reynolds/AFP via Getty Images)
item.dc:creator: Bill Chappell

item.title: Here are the legal next steps in the Trump documents case
item.description: Former President Donald Trump has pleaded not guilty to the 37 counts against him. While special counsel Jack Smith wants a speedy trial, Trump's lawyers could file motions that would delay it.
item.content:encoded:
Former President Donald Trump has pleaded not guilty to the 37 counts against him. While special counsel Jack Smith wants a speedy trial, Trump's lawyers could file motions that would delay it.

(Image credit: Giorgio Viera/AFP via Getty Images)
item.dc:creator: NPR Washington Desk

item.title: Attorney General Garland defends special counsel's integrity in Trump indictment
item.description: In the face of allegations of bias, Attorney General Merrick Garland called Jack Smith a "veteran career prosecutor" with a "commitment to integrity and the rule of law."
item.content:encoded:
In the face of allegations of bias, Attorney General Merrick Garland called Jack Smith a "veteran career prosecutor" with a "commitment to integrity and the rule of law."

(Image credit: Mandel Ngan/AFP via Getty Images)
item.dc:creator: Carrie Johnson

item.title: Taking a breather: Fed holds interest rates steady in patient battle against inflation
item.description: After 10 straight rate hikes, the Federal Reserve left interest rates unchanged Wednesday, but hinted that additional rate hikes are possible if inflation remains stubbornly high.
item.content:encoded:
After 10 straight rate hikes, the Federal Reserve left interest rates unchanged Wednesday, but hinted that additional rate hikes are possible if inflation remains stubbornly high.

(Image credit: Mark Wilson/Getty Images)
item.dc:creator: Scott Horsley

item.title: The U.S. Army renames a base in honor of Sgt. William Henry Johnson, a Black WWI hero
item.description: Louisiana's Fort Polk became Fort Johnson, the latest Army base to replace its Confederate name. It now honors a soldier who earned a Medal of Honor a century after the night that made him a hero.
item.content:encoded:
Louisiana's Fort Polk became Fort Johnson, the latest Army base to replace its Confederate name. It now honors a soldier who earned a Medal of Honor a century after the night that made him a hero.

(Image credit: New York National Guard)
item.dc:creator: Rachel Treisman

item.title: Southern Baptists say no to women pastors, uphold expulsion of Saddleback megachurch
item.description: The Southern Baptist Convention upheld the removal of two churches for having women as pastors. The nearly 13,000 voters, called "messengers," voted overwhelmingly to uphold the churches' removals.
item.content:encoded:
The Southern Baptist Convention upheld the removal of two churches for having women as pastors. The nearly 13,000 voters, called "messengers," voted overwhelmingly to uphold the churches' removals.

(Image credit: Allison Dinner/AP)
item.dc:creator: Jason DeRose

item.title: 'It's gonna be a hot labor summer' — unionized workers show up for striking writers
item.description: Film and TV writers on strike may soon be joined by actors currently negotiating their contract. As the writers strike enters its seventh week, unions beyond Hollywood are joining the movement.
item.content:encoded:
Film and TV writers on strike may soon be joined by actors currently negotiating their contract. As the writers strike enters its seventh week, unions beyond Hollywood are joining the movement.

(Image credit: Mandalit del Barco/NPR)
item.dc:creator: Mandalit del Barco
